descriptions: Teams net points while player is on the court.
Teams net points while player is on the court.

article.description:
Gary Payton scored 20 points as the Seattle SuperSonics beat Detroit 117-89 Saturday night, the Pistons' fifth
straight loss on a dismal West Coast trip.
article.headline: Sonics deny Pistons, win fourth straight
article.linkText: West Coast woes: Reeling Pistons lose fifth straight
article.story:
SEATTLE (AP) -- The Seattle SuperSonics weren't about to blow another 22-point halftime lead.
Payton

Seattle built a comfortable 22-point advantage in the first half and then shot 66 percent from the floor in the last two periods in a 117-89 victory over the Detroit Pistons on Saturday night. One night after squandering a 22-point halftime lead and beating Golden State in overtime, the SuperSonics extended their winning streak to four games. "We knew we just had to stay focused. We didn't stay focused the other night, and we didn't make our shots," said Gary Payton, whose 20 points led six Sonics in double figures. "Plus, there's a big difference being up by 22 at home. Things seem to happen on the road when you're up like that." Pistons leading scorer Jerry Stackhouse was ejected with three minutes to go in the second quarter for arguing a non-call with referee Leon Wood. Stackhouse had 18 points at the time, after scoring 14 of the Pistons' first 16 points. "I saw Gary gather the guys and let them know right away that we have to continue to play, which is a key. You don't let down when one of those stars leaves the game, the way we did in the Lakers game," Sonics coach Nate McMillan said. Shaquille O'Neal was ejected in the first quarter of the Lakers' 107-92 victory over Seattle on Nov. 30. The Sonics improved to 13-15 and snapped a string of eight consecutive losses in the second of back-to-back games this season. "I like our defense the last couple of games," McMillan said. "That may be due to us having our legs back under us, having some days off to rest and get ready for games" before the Golden State game. The loss was the fifth straight on a dismal West Coast road swing for Detroit (14-11), which began the trip in first place in the Central Division but has fallen a game behind Milwaukee. "There are a lot of excuses we can make," Pistons coach Rick Carlisle said. "This is an effort that is beneath the dignity of what we've been about up until now. "I thought there has been one other game, maybe two, where we just didn't have it. We've got a lot of work to do." Against Golden State on Friday, the Sonics scored just 27 points in the second half of regulation. They scored 55 points and shot 23-for-35 in the second half against Detroit. Seattle outscored Detroit 50-24 in the paint and outrebounded the Pistons 34-29. Detroit never got closer than 21 points in the second half. "That's what it's all about," the Sonics' Desmond Mason said. "You play defense like that, you get easy baskets." Rashard Lewis and Vladimir Radmanovic each added 18 for Seattle, which shot 60.5 percent from the field for the game. Reserve center Art Long had a career-high 13. The Sonics were without starting power forward Vin Baker, who sprained his right thumb against Golden State. Baker was listed as day-to-day. Chucky Atkins had 13 points and Jon Barry had 12 for the Pistons, who couldn't get into a scoring rhythm after Stackhouse's ejection. "It was a little bit of everything, tired legs, lack of focus. You need to come out with more energy than that," Detroit's Ben Wallace said. The Pistons lost 83-81 in Portland on Friday night. Seattle rookie Radmanovic, who started in place of Baker, hit three 3-pointers in the fourth quarter, then put a scare into his coaches. Radmanovic stole the ball, raced the length of the floor for a dunk and nearly did a back flip before hitting the floor hard on his back. He walked off under his own power after about a minute but sustained a mild concussion and was to be evaluated on Sunday. The Sonics used a 24-6 run, capped by Stackhouse's ejection, to take a 55-33 lead in the second quarter. Seattle led 62-40 at halftime. Game notes
The 30-point loss was not Detroit's worst to Seattle. That was a 40-point blowout, 134-94, on March 12, 1995. ... Detroit's Jon Barry holds a 9-3 advantage in the all-time series against brother Brent Barry's teams. Both sons of Hall of Famer Rick Barry are averaging career highs in points this season: Jon with 9.0 and Brent with 14.1 for the Sonics. ... Atkins hit a 49-foot 3-pointer at the first-quarter buzzer. He took the running shot several feet behind the half-court line.

statistics.name: points
statistics.description: The number of points scored.

statistics.name: fieldGoals
statistics.description: Field Goal makes and attempts.

statistics.name: freeThrows
statistics.description: Free Throw makes and attempts.

statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.
